document.masterDocTitle: A study of the Iranian species of Choeras Mason (Hymenoptera: Braconidae: Microgastrinae), with the description of a new species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A study of the Iranian species of Choeras Mason (Hymenoptera: Braconidae: Microgastrinae), with the description of a new species

Short diagnosis. Female ( Iran ), length of body 3.0â€“ 3.3 mm , length of antenna 2.7â€“2.9 mm , length of fore wing 2.7â€“2.9 mm .

Colour. Body colour paler than typical European specimens. Mesoscutum, mesoscutellum, metanotum, propodeum, propleuron, mesopleuron, metapleuron, T1â€“T2 and anterior margin of T3 entirely brownish orange ( Figs 7G , 8Aâ€“8D ). Metacoxa, metafemur, metatibia and tibial spurs orange ( Figs 7A, 7C, 7G , 8E ). Pterostigma with a pale spot at about anterior 0.4 and remainder brown ( Fig. 8A ). Ovipositor sheath tricolored, basally yellow, then orange brown, and apically dark brown ( Fig. 8E ).

Mesosoma .
Mesosoma 1.4 Ã— as long as wide ( Figs 7G , 8A ). Scutoscutellar sulcus with 9 or 10 carinae and/or pits ( Figs 8Aâ€“8B ). Mesopleuron completely smooth and posteriorly largely glabrous. Metapleuron mostly smooth anteriorly and rugose with long setae posteriorly ( Fig. 7G ). Propodeum shiny with surface smooth, rugose near irregular medio-longitudinal carina, transverse carina represented by some rugae, medio-posteriorly with four carinae ( Fig. 8B ).
Legs. Tarsal claws slender and only setose. Metacoxa surpassing posterior margin of T2 ( Figs 7A, 7G , 8E ). Metafemur 1.2 Ã— as long as metatibia ( Figs 7A , 8E ).

Wings. Fore wing: vein R1 nearly equal (0.9 Ã—) to pterostigma length and vein r of fore wing 0.7 Ã— as long as vein 2 RS and straight, stub of vein r-m of fore wing usually medium-sized, vein r-m 0.9 Ã— as long as 3RSa, vein r about 0.5 Ã— pterostigma width. Hind wing: vein cu-a curved ( Fig. 8F ).

Distribution in Iran :
Qazvin (
Ghahari et al. 2011b
) and Kermanshah provinces.
Biology. Unknown and only collected in May.

tiro
(Reinhard)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Similar species. The most similar species is
C. suffolciensis ( Morley, 1902 )
. Females of this species have an unusually widened pterostigma that is completely dark brown, without a pale blotch at its base, with antenna long and setae very noticeable and pilose, T1 slightly narrowed posteriorly and not noticeably wedge-shaped.

Notes. The aberrant apex of antenna, the curious appearance of the flagellum, the shape of T1 and pale blotch at base of the pterostigma are reliable characters to recognize this species. The differences in colour most likely are caused by the climatological differences between Iran and Europe. The identity of the Iranian specimen(s) reported by
Ghahari et al. (2011b)
could not be assessed because the depository was not mentioned.
